fact: Foxes are the most widespread wild canids in the world, inhabiting every continent except Antarctica.
There are over 30 different species of fox, with the red fox (Vulpes vulpes) being the most common.
Despite being in the dog family (Canidae), foxes share many characteristics with cats, including vertical pupils and a similar stalking hunting style.
True foxes belong to the genus Vulpes. Other animals with 'fox' in their name, like the grey fox, belong to different genera.
Foxes can leap over 6 feet (2 metres) in the air.
Unlike most other canids, some fox species have partially retractable claws, which helps them climb.

Foxes are believed to be the first animals discovered to use the Earth's magnetic field to hunt. They can see the field as a 'ring of shadow' that helps them pinpoint prey in deep snow or thick vegetation.
A fox can hear a mouse squeak from 100 feet away and can even hear low-frequency sounds of animals digging underground.
In addition to the whiskers on their faces, foxes have vibrissae on their legs, which help them navigate in the dark.
A fox's tail, or 'brush,' is used for balance, as a warm cover in cold weather, and for communication.
Many red foxes have a white tip on their tail, a feature that helps them communicate with each other in low light.
While many foxes have amber-coloured eyes, their eye colour can also be brown or even blue in some cases.
Like cats and other canids, foxes walk on their toes, which allows for their silent, stealthy movements.
Foxes have a tapetum lucidum in their eyes, a reflective layer that enhances their vision in low-light conditions.
While they can be active during the day, foxes are primarily nocturnal or crepuscular (active at dawn and dusk).
A fox's coat changes with the seasons, becoming thicker and denser in the winter for insulation and lighter in the summer.
Foxes have scent glands at the base of their tail and on their paws, which they use to mark their territory.
Foxes have a distinct musky odour, which is particularly strong during the breeding season.
Their long, narrow snout is an adaptation for foraging in small holes and crevices for prey.
Red foxes can run at speeds of up to 30 miles per hour (48 kilometres per hour).
In the wild, the average lifespan of a fox is short, typically 2 to 4 years. In captivity, they can live for more than 10 years.
The largest fox species is the red fox, while the smallest is the fennec fox.
The fennec fox has disproportionately large ears that help dissipate heat in its desert habitat.
The Arctic fox has a white coat in the winter to blend in with the snow and a brown or grey coat in the summer.
The grey fox is one of the only canids capable of climbing trees, thanks to its strong, hooked claws.
Foxes are omnivores, meaning they eat a wide variety of foods, including small mammals, birds, reptiles, insects, fruits, and berries.
Unlike wolves, foxes are not pack hunters and typically hunt alone.
Foxes have a characteristic hunting pounce where they leap high into the air and bring their front paws down on their prey.
Foxes often cache excess food, burying it to eat later. They have an excellent memory for where they've stored their meals.
In urban environments, foxes have adapted to scavenging for food from rubbish bins and compost heaps.
A significant portion of a fox's diet, especially in some regions, can be made up of earthworms.
Foxes have a sweet tooth and are known to enjoy fruits like apples, blackberries, and cherries.
In the summer months, a large part of their diet can consist of insects like grasshoppers and beetles.
A single fox can eat thousands of rodents in a year, playing a crucial role in controlling their populations.
Foxes are opportunistic feeders and will eat almost anything they can find.
They use a slow, cat-like stalk to approach their prey before launching a final, swift attack.
Their incredible hearing allows them to locate prey moving under snow or soil.
Their adaptable diet is a key reason for their widespread success as a species.
Foxes will also feed on carrion (dead animals).
Most of their hunting and foraging activities take place at night.
Foxes are highly vocal and have a wide range of calls, including barks, screams, howls, and chatters. They can produce up to 40 different vocalisations.
A series of guttural chattering sounds, known as 'gekkering,' is often heard during disputes.
The eerie, high-pitched scream of a vixen is most commonly heard during the mating season.
Foxes communicate extensively through body language, using their ears, tail, and posture to convey messages.
Urine and faeces are used to mark territorial boundaries and communicate with other foxes.
While often solitary, foxes can live in small family groups, known as a 'skulk' or 'leash' of foxes.
A typical fox family consists of a breeding pair (dog fox and vixen) and their offspring.
Sometimes, young from a previous litter will stay with their parents to help raise the next litter of kits.
Foxes are territorial animals and will defend their home range from other foxes.
Foxes are known to be playful, both with each other and with objects they find. They have been observed stealing golf balls to play with.
Within a family group, there is a clear dominance hierarchy.
Foxes will groom each other to strengthen social bonds.
Like dogs, foxes may wag their tails to express excitement or submission.
A submissive fox will lower its body, flatten its ears, and avert its gaze.
Foxes often form monogamous pairs for the breeding season, and some pairs may stay together for life.
The breeding season for most fox species is in the winter, typically from January to March.
The gestation period for a vixen is around 53 days.
Vixens give birth to their young, called kits or pups, in underground dens.
A litter of fox kits can range from one to eleven, with an average of four to five.
Fox kits are born blind, deaf, and toothless.
Newborn kits are covered in dark, fuzzy fur.
The vixen stays with her kits in the den for the first few weeks, while the male brings her food.
The dog fox plays an active role in raising the young, providing food for both the vixen and the kits.
Kits are weaned at around four to five weeks of age.
The kits begin to emerge from the den at about four to five weeks old.
The parents teach the kits how to hunt by bringing them live prey to practise on.
Young foxes typically leave their parents' territory in the autumn to establish their own.
Foxes reach sexual maturity at around 10 months of age.
Foxes typically have only one litter of kits per year.
Foxes may dig their own dens or enlarge the burrows of other animals like rabbits or badgers.
Fox dens often have multiple entrances to allow for a quick escape from predators.
Fox dens are also known as 'earths' or 'burrows'.
In cities, foxes may create dens under sheds, in basements, or in other sheltered urban spaces.
In many cultures, the fox is a symbol of cunning, trickery, and intelligence.
Foxes feature prominently in the folklore and mythology of many countries, often as clever characters.
The practice of hunting foxes with hounds has been a controversial topic for centuries.
Healthy foxes are generally not a threat to humans and will typically avoid contact.
Foxes have proven to be incredibly adaptable and have successfully colonised many urban and suburban areas.
Foxes can be carriers of rabies, although this is more common in some regions than others.
Sarcoptic mange, a skin disease caused by mites, can be a significant threat to fox populations.
By preying on rodents and rabbits, foxes can be beneficial to farmers.
However, they can also be a nuisance to farmers by preying on poultry and small livestock.
Feeding wild foxes can make them dependent on humans and lose their natural fear, which can lead to negative interactions.
A long-term experiment in Russia has successfully domesticated silver foxes, a colour morph of the red fox.
While some wild foxes can become tame, they are not domesticated animals.
A group of foxes is called a 'skulk' or a 'leash'.
A male fox is called a 'dog,' 'todd,' or 'reynard,' and a female is a 'vixen'.
The swift fox, native to North America, is one of the fastest canids and can reach speeds of over 30 mph.
The bat-eared fox, an African species, has enormous ears that it uses to locate termites, its primary food source.
Found in South America, the crab-eating fox has a diet that includes a significant amount of crabs.
The island fox, found on the Channel Islands of California, is one of the smallest fox species in the world.
The corsac fox, from central Asia, is known for its ability to survive in arid environments and can go for long periods without water.
The Tibetan sand fox has a distinctively square face and is found on the Tibetan Plateau.

The red fox is the suspected source of the mysterious 'Wow!' signal, a strong narrowband radio signal detected in 1977, due to its vocalisation patterns. While not confirmed, it remains a fascinating theory.
Foxes do not hibernate and remain active throughout the winter.
Foxes are capable swimmers.
They often travel along the same routes, creating visible paths in their territory.
The tail of a red fox can be up to two-thirds the length of its head and body.
Natural predators of foxes include eagles, coyotes, wolves, bears, and mountain lions.
Their intelligence, adaptability, and resourcefulness have allowed foxes to thrive in a wide range of environments around the world.
